keyTakeAways: George Santos, a former U.S. Representative from New York, was released from prison after President Donald Trump commuted his seven-year sentence for fraud charges.
Santos claims his prosecution was not political and that he has experienced a 'very large slice of humble pie' during his time in prison.
Despite the commutation, critics including Rep. Nick LaLota and Rep. Andrew Garbarino continue to argue that Santos' crimes warranted harsher punishment and that he shows no remorse.
Santos states he will not return to politics within the next decade, citing his age and personal fatigue from political life.
He is now focusing on prison reform, stating that solitary confinement contributes to recidivism and that he wants to work on reform in a non-partisan manner.
Santos is no longer required to pay fines, restitution, or fulfill probation conditions due to the clemency granted by the President.
He claims he did not commit fraud in his campaign and says the investment made to win an election was legitimate.

summaryOfNewsArticle: George Santos, a former U.S. Representative from New York who was imprisoned for fraud charges, was released from prison after President Donald Trump commuted his seven-year sentence. Santos claims the prosecution was not political and that he has accepted accountability, stating he now focuses on prison reform and personal growth. Despite the commutation, critics like Rep. Nick LaLota and Rep. Andrew Garbarino argue that the sentence was too lenient and that Santos lacks remorse. Santos denies fraud allegations, stating he only made campaign investments to win an election, and says he will not return to politics in the next decade. He is now committed to advocating for prison reform, citing the harmful effects of solitary confinement and recidivism.
title: George Santos maintains his prosecution was political, says he’s had a ‘very large slice of humble pie’
